citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs was not available for review during this inspection. A total of 337 adult guinea pigs,
weanlings, and newborns were counted during this inspection. There were no inventory records kept and maintained
since the previous inspection report. Failure to maintain these records makes it difficult to assess the health of the caviary
by identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pigs born, raised, or died. The licensee must maintain
records containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, acquired
or disposed of including births and deaths. Remains uncorrected.

Storage. There is an open bag of guinea pig feed and an open bag of shavings on the floor of the animal room. Failure to
store food and bedding supplies adequately can result in spoilage, deterioration or contamination from pests. Open bags
of feed must be stored in containers with lids or covers to protect supplies from contamination. Open bags of shavings
should not be stored directly on the floor to protect the the bedding from moisture or contaminated by pests. Correct by
April 1, 2023.

Feeding. The self-feeders on the sides of the guinea pig enclosures were covered with dust, dirt, and cobwebs. Failure to
keep the self-feeders clean can result in deterioration or contamination of the feed. All food receptacles must be kept
clean and feeders must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by March 30, 2023.

There are accumulations of dust, dirt, and cobwebs covering the sides of the guinea pig enclosures, racks, walls, ceiling,
window sills, and drainage pipes. There is hay, empty bags, shavings, and excreta on the floor of the animal room. Animal
facilities must be kept clean to ensure good quality of the air for the animals and to prevent unnecessary disease risks.
Correct by ensuring the premises are kept clean, including: removing accumulations of dust, dirt, cobwebs and debris
from surfaces; routinely cleaning surfaces and the floor of the animal room; and maintaining a level of general cleanliness
to support good animal husbandry and health. Remains uncorrected.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs was not available for review during this inspection. A total of 337 adult guinea pigs, 
weanlings, and newborns were counted during this inspection. There were no inventory records kept and maintained 
since the previous inspection report. Failure to maintain these records makes it difficult to assess the health of the caviary 
by identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pigs born, raised, or died. The licensee must maintain 
records containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, acquired 
or disposed of including births and deaths. Remains uncorrected. 
3.25(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Storage. There is an open bag of guinea pig feed and an open bag of shavings on the floor of the animal room. Failure to 
store food and bedding supplies adequately can result in spoilage, deterioration or contamination from pests. Open bags 
of feed must be stored in containers with lids or covers to protect supplies from contamination. Open bags of shavings 
should not be stored directly on the floor to protect the the bedding from moisture or contaminated by pests.  Correct by 
April 1, 2023. 
3.29(d) 
   
Feeding.

Feeding. The self-feeders on the sides of the guinea pig enclosures were covered with dust, dirt, and cobwebs. Failure to 
keep the self-feeders clean can result in deterioration or contamination of the feed. All food receptacles must be kept 
clean and feeders must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by March 30, 2023. 
3.31(b)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
There are accumulations of dust, dirt, and cobwebs covering the sides of the guinea pig enclosures, racks, walls, ceiling, 
window sills, and drainage pipes. There is hay, empty bags, shavings, and excreta on the floor of the animal room. Animal 
facilities must be kept clean to ensure good quality of the air for the animals and to prevent unnecessary disease risks. 
Correct by ensuring the premises are kept clean, including: removing accumulations of dust, dirt, cobwebs and debris 
from surfaces; routinely cleaning surfaces and the floor of the animal room; and maintaining a level of general cleanliness 
to support good animal husbandry and health. Remains uncorrected. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
